result.execSummary:
The defendant Jason Napiwocki was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Mislead Buyer When Signing Documents, an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes ATCP110.02(6)(d).
  • Home Improvement Contract Violation, an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes ATCP110.05(2)(a).
  • Theft-Business Setting <=$2500, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(b).
  • Misappropriate Buyer Prepayments Under Home Improvement Contract, an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes ATCP110.02(10).
  • Misrepresent Home Improvement Contract, an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes ATCP110.02(11).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

Defendant Jason Napiwocki in court. Prosecuting Assistant District Attorney (ADA) Robert J Jambois appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

11:36 AM Court calls case.
Atty  Jambois states appearances.

Defendant appears without counsel.
This is a hearing requested by probation and parole.

Agent is not present.
Atty Jambois addresses the Court.

Atty Jambois hands to Court a letter he received from probation and parole. Defendant received a copy of the letter this morning.
Court takes a moment to read the letter. 

The letter is an email correspondence from J.G.
Court received a memo indicating that the last time Defendant appeared at a review hearing, was that Defendant was arranging to take a loan to pay restitution. This was late October.
The Court's understanding is that the loan process is ongoing. Defendant has been out of the state prior to the holidays due to work training.

Agent proposed, is to extend the term of probation for a period of 1 year with the understanding that if/when Defendant secures the loan and with payment to victim, that would discharge further obligations on the probation extension.
Atty Jambois concurs, this is his understanding as well. 
Defendant agrees as well.

BY THE COURT:
Probation is to be extended for 1 year. Once loan is successful and restitution is paid, this will terminate probation.

Court signs the order.
Probation review hearing on December 27, 2018 at 11:30 am.
Letter from DOC dated 12/12/18 in re:  Defendant unable to attend the Probation Review Hearing on 12/17/18 as he will be in Tennessee for training
Probation review hearing on December 17, 2018 at 11:30 am.

Defendant Jason Napiwocki in court. Prosecuting Assistant District Attorney (ADA) Robert J Jambois appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Probation Agent, Sara, appears in person.

2:03 p.m.  Case is called and appearances are stated. 

Hearing today is in regards to unpaid restitution.
State indicates that the defendant is attempting to get a loan to pay off the restitution.
State provides the agreement on the record.
Court questions the defendant.
State would ask that this be hold over for a couple of months for the defendant to get his loan.
State would not have any issue to the court costs being turned into a civil judgment.
State is more interested in making sure the restitution is paid.
Court makes statements on the record with regards to the payment of the restitution.
Court asks the victim to come up to the podium to ask some questions; the plan as stated on the record is agreed upon by the victim.
The balance of the restitution as of today's date is $39,636.62.
If the restitution is paid off prior to the Probation Review Hearing date of December 17, 2018 the State will prepare a stipulation for the Court to sign.
State indicates that if there is any monies outstanding for costs/fines that this will then be converted to a civil judgment.

BY THE COURT:
Case is to be set for a Probation Review Hearing. 
  Probation review hearing scheduled for December 17, 2018 at 11:30 am.

Defendant Jason Napiwocki in court. Daniel R. Hess appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Probation Agent is also present.

8:48 AM Court calls case.

Matter is set for a review hearing.

Atty Hess addresses the Court, Probation Agent is requesting probation be extended due to the fact that restitution has not been paid in full.
Defendant has been refusing to sign the extension paperwork and requsted a hearing.

On 8/4/15, a restitution hearing was held, which resulted an order for Defendant to pay $100 per week for restitution.
Since 8/4/15, $6,920 has been paid leaving balance of just under $56,000.  Payments have been sporadic during probation.

Defendant addresses the Court.

Court questions Defendant.
Defendant replies.

Discussions continue as to finances.

Probation Agent addresses the Court as to budget, requests an extension on probation and requests payments of $100 per week.
Atty Hess addresses the Court.

Defendant provides to the Court a list of monthly bills.

Probation Agent addresses the Court, victim is present in the courtroom and states victim is struggling with trying to get the repairs fixed.
Exhibit #1 is marked on behalf of Defendant.

BY THE COURT:
Court continues restitution as previously ordered by Judge Mason and extend the probationary period another 12 months.

If problems develop thereafter, may have to consider civil judgment route.
Atty Hess will meet with victim after today's hearing.
/s/ RJS 11/28/17 - Atty Chris Donovan is allowed to withdraw as counsel

Defendant Jason Napiwocki in court. Cass W Cousins appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Ms. Hohenstein in court.

9:45 am  Case is called.
This is set for a hearing on a letter from the Department of Corrections re: restitution.

Court questions Atty Cousins re: if he received the letter.
Atty Cousins responds.
Defendant makes statements to the Court.
Court questions Defendant.
Atty Cousins makes arguments to the Court.
Court questions Ms. Hohenstein.
Ms. Hohenstein makes statements to the Court.

BY THE COURT:
Court doesn't have authority to proceed on an evidentiary basis.  Ms. Hohenstein's letter is not a proper motion before the Court.
Court requires Defendant to file a motion for modification of the Court's prior Order that would establish the burden upon him to make sufficient proofs to the Court to make the modification.

Court questions Defendant re: if he is still represented.
Defendant responds re: he cannot afford an attorney.
Hearing on June 7, 2017 at 09:30 am.
IT IS ORDERED that the motion for summary reversal is denied.

/s/ RJS 06/07/16 **Defendant's Motion to Vacate the Restitution Order and Hold New Restitution Hearing is Denied.

Defendant Jason Napiwocki in court with attorney Christopher Donovan, both appearing by telephone. Cass W Cousins appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
3:40 p.m. case is called and appearances stated on the record.  
This is a motion hearing seeking to vacate the restitution order.  
Attorney Donovan states his position on the record.  
ADA Cousins states its position on the record.  
Attorney Donovan responds to the state's position.

BTC:  
Court denies the motion finding no irregularity in the statutory process followed and absent some relative law specifically a restitution hearing that would require or permit a De Novo hearing for the relief sought by the defendant.  Under the circumstances and the transcripts reviewed, Court denies the motion.  

Attorney Donovan will provide a proposed Order to the court for signature.

3:59 p.m. case is concluded.
IT IS ORDERED that the extension motion is granted.  The time to file a notice of appeal is hereby extended to July 1, 2016.

Defendant Jason Napiwocki in court with attorney Jared Redfield. Cass W Cousins appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
FTR:  02:46 a.m. case is called and appearances stated on the record.
Court swears in the first witness.  Court asks the witness to explain the reason why he believes he is owed restitution.  
Witness makes statement to the court.  
ADA makes statement to the court re: case #14CF50.
9:05 a.m.  ADA examines the witness (J. Grezinski)  
9:07 a.m.  Attorney Redfield objects re: contract.  Court overrules.  ADA continues examination.  
9:18 a.m.  Cross examination of witness by Attorney Redfield.  
9:20 a.m.  Objection by ADA re: argumentative.  Court sustains.  Attorney Redfield continues cross examination.  
9:25 a.m.  ADA redirect of witness.  
9:28 a.m.  Clerk marks Exhibits.  ADA refers to Exhibits in redirect. 
9:31 a.m.  Attorney Redfield objects - re: foundation.  Court overrules.  
9:32 a.m.  ADA moves for admission of Exhibits 1 - 4.  Attorney Redfield objects.  Court admits the exhibits into evidence.  
ADA questions contract was an exhibit.  Court indicates it has not been received into evidence yet.
9:33 a.m.  Clerk marks Exhibit #5.  ADA refers in re-direct.  
Attorney Redfield ask that his copy of contract be attached to Exhibit #8.  
ADA continues redirect.  
9:36 a.m.  ADA moves for admission of Exhibit #5.  Court receives into evidence.  No objections by Attorney Redfield.
9:37 a.m.  Attorney Redfield calls the next witness.  Court swears in the witness.  (J. Lochinger).  Attorney Redfield examines the witness.  
9:44 a.m.  Cross examination by ADA Cousins.  
9:51 a.m.  Attorney Redfield calls next witness.  Court swears in the witness (J. Napiwocki).  Attorney Redfield examines the witness.  
10:18 a.m.  Cross examine by ADA Cousins.
10:31 a.m.  Objection by Attorney Redfield.  Court sustains.  Cross examination continues by ADA Cousins.
10:32 a.m.  Witness steps down.  Attorney Redfield calls next witness, court swears in the witness (Ms. Denise Napiwocki).  Examination by Attorney Redfield.  
10:34 a.m.  ADA cross examination of witness.  
10:35 a.m.   Witness steps down.
ADA makes closing statement to the court.
10:40 a.m.  Attorney Redfield makes closing statement to the court.  
10:49 a.m.  ADA makes additional statement to the court.  Attorney Redfield objects.  Court overrules.
ADa makes additional statement.

Court explains the procedure and that its the ultimate decision of Judge Finn and informs the parties they will get his written decision.

10:51:12 case is concluded.

Defendant Jason Napiwocki in court with attorney Jared Redfield. Cass W Cousins appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Amended Information filed.  Plea questionnaire/Agreement filed.
Prosecutor states plea agreement. Count 1, 2, 4, 5, & 6: 3 yrs Probation: Pay restitution of $65,200.00. Conditions: 
Attorney for Defendant concurs with agreement stated and states to the Court that the Parties are not in agreement for the amount of any restitution.
Court informs a restitution hearing would be heard in front of the Court Commissioner.

Defendant enters a plea of:  No Contest to amended Information Count 1, 2, 4, 5, & 6.

Court questions Defendant regarding plea.
Court informs Defendant of Constitutional Rights. Court advises Defendant of Elements State must prove for the Charge.
Court questions Attorney for Defendant.
Court finds Defendant's Plea is freely, voluntarily and intelligently made.
Attorneys stipulate that there is factual basis for the charge(s).

BY THE COURT:
Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charge(s).
Court finds the defendant guilty 1, 2, 4 5 & 6.  Clerk directed to enter Judgment of Conviction this date. Ct 3 is Dismissed Read In.
Victim Impact Statement letter is provided and the Court reviews same.  
Court has it marked as exhibit #P1 and is made part of the record.
ADA Cousins makes sentencing arguments to the Court and requests to give the Probation Agent the tools to track financial status and ensure payment of restitution with option to have luxury items be sold to pay off restitution.  Also to have a restitution review hearing down the line 3 to 5 months from now to review status of payments.
Atty Redfield concurs in part for joint recommendation of probation, but makes sentencing arguments to the Court and will be requesting a restitution hearing in front of court commissioner.
Defendant makes apologetic statements.

BY THE COURT:*******************PROBATION********************
Count 1: W/H Sentence 3 yrs Probation: Pay restitution of $65,200.00. Conditions:  Defendant to provide a financial statements so agent can determine how much and ability to pay.  Be employed full time, no work as independant contractor. Pay $25 fine + costs.  Pay Restitution surcharges. No DNA surcharge ordered on any of the counts. Restitition Hearing needs to be scheduled with Court Commissioner.
Count 2:  W/H Sentence 3 yrs Probation, concurrent. Comply with conditions in Count 1.   Pay $25 fine + costs.
Count 4: W/H Sentence 3 yrs Probation, concurrent. Comply with conditions in Count 1 & 2.   Pay costs.
Count 5: W/H Sentence 3 yrs Probation, concurrent. Comply with conditions in Count 1, 2,& 4 .   Pay $25 fine + costs.
Count 6: W/H Sentence 3 yrs Probation, concurrent. Comply with conditions in Count 1, 2, 4, &5.   Pay $25 fine + costs.
